awd_titl_txt: Use of Diamond-Like Carbon Coatings to Reduce Leachables From Biomedical Metal Alloys and Polymeric Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The Food & Drug Administration (FDA) requires that manufacturers assure the safety of medical devices or products that contact body tissues/fluids. Therefore, it is vital to minimize the release of chemical species, commonly known as leachables and extractables, from medical devices. The presence of these species may be due not only to the chemical composition of the materials, but also from manufacturing processes. Leachables and extractables from medical device biomaterials may have a significant impact on biocompatibility and may pose significant risks to patient health. This project will minimize the release of leachables from several classes of common biomaterials, including (a) polyvinylchloride (used in intravenous tubing and blood storage bags), (b) additively manufactured polyetheretherketone (used in bone implants), and (c) nickel-titanium shape memory alloy (used in cardiovascular stents for vessel patency), by depositing hydrogenated diamond-like carbon (DLC) coatings on the surfaces of these materials. DLC is a  material made up entirely of carbon atoms, it can serve as a cell-friendly permeation barrier that prevents the release of leachables. This inexpensive technology has been utilized to prevent oxygen permeation in the bottled beverage industry. A DLC coating that would be chemically-amenable on polymers or metal alloys used in medical devices would reduce leachable-associated health risks across many classes of materials.


The project has three aims. Aim 1: Deposition of DLC coatings on model biomaterials using plasma enhanced physical vapor deposition and physico-chemical characterization of the coatings. Scanning electron microscopy will be used to confirm the absence of pinholes in the coating, to confirm the coating thickness, and to evaluate the surface morphology. Aim 2: Chemical characterization and toxicological risk assessment of extractables and leachables from uncoated and DLC-coated biomaterials under physiologic and worst-case conditions. The milestone for this deliverable will be a comparison of the release of extractables and leachables from the DLC coated materials compared to uncoated materials. A toxicologic hazard identification assessment will be conducted to determine if any of the materials pose a toxicological risk. Aim 3: Biocompatibility testing of extractables/leachables from coated and uncoated/DLC-coated biomaterials using in vitro assays. The extractables and leachables from both uncoated and DLC-coated biomaterials will be used to treat mammalian cells in vitro for assessment of cell viability, reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and pro-inflammatory cell markers. The goal is to confirm if DLC coatings reduce extractables/leachables from biomaterials that are commonly used in medical devices. If the proposed project is successful, the medical device industry will have a material (DLC) for application to a wide variety of metals and polymers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal is to minimize the release of leachables from several classes of common biomaterials, including (a) polyvinylchloride (used in intravenous tubing and bags for blood and dialysis fluid storage), (b) 3D-printed acrylate-based polymer (used in bioMEMS devices), and (c) nickel-titanium shape memory alloy (used in cardiovascular stents, orthodontic archwires, and birth control devices) by depositing hydrogenated diamond-like carbon (DLC) coatings on the surfaces of these materials. DLC is an amorphous material that contains both sp^2- and sp^3- hybridized carbon atoms, which is deposited on biomaterials using plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition. Since DLC is a high atomic density material made up entirely of carbon atoms, it can serve as a cell-friendly permeation barrier that prevents the release of leachables. This inexpensive technology has been utilized to prevent oxygen permeation in the bottled beverage industry. A DLC coating that could be deposited on the surfaces of polymers or metals used in medical devices would have the potential to reduce leachable-associated health risks across many classes of medical devices.

National Science Foundation funding was used to support the training of two North Carolina State University PhD students in the benchtop biological testing of new types of materials at the Food & Drug Administration facilities in Silver Spring, Maryland.

In one study, plasma treatment was performed using an Oxford Plasmalab 80 Plusreactive ion etcher to make the surface of the diamond-like carbon coating oxygen- or fluorine-terminated. Water contact angle measurements were performed with ten replicate measurements; contact angle values were recorded after aging for 5 s for each sample. The results were 91.0±0.7° (Si-DLC), 50.4±1.4° (oxygen plasma-modified Si-DLC), and 81.0±1.0° (fluorine plasma-modified Si-DLC). Oxygen plasma treatment rendered the surface hydrophilic, while fluorine plasma treatment rendered the surface more hydrophobic. Fungal cell assessment was evaluated at North Dakota State University by crystal violet (CV) quantification with fungal pathogen Candida albicans. Oxygen plasma-treated coatings showed less attachment of eukaryotic (fungal) cells than untreated surfaces of fluorine plasma-treated coatings. Oxygen plasma-modified Si-DLC demonstrated the highest % inhibition with 99.5%, while % inhibitions were 22.8% and 24% for fluorine plasma-modified Si-DLC and Si-DLC, respectively. The result indicated that a hydrophilic surface would have higher inhibition for biofilm attachment. Reducing the attachment of cells may enhance the functionality of many types of medical devices.

In an additional study, a radio frequency (RF) Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PECVD) system located at  North Carolina State University (NCSU) was used for silicon-incorporated (Si-DLC) coatings on polymer and silicon surfaces. The effect of surface modification of Si-DLC on hydrophobicity was correlated with the viability of L929 mouse fibroblasts. Confocal microscopy and viability studies showed that oxygen-treated Si-DLC showed higher cell viability rates compared to untreated Si-DLC and fluorine-treated Si-DLC 120 hours after seeding. The higher cell viability rate was correlated with the conversion of the hydrophobic surface of Si-DLC into a hydrophilic surface through oxygen plasma treatment.

In an additional study, the moisture vapor transmission rate of a Si-DLC-coated commercial polymer bag material was evaluated. The moisture transmission barrier properties of Si-DLC-coated polymer bag material were assessed using moisture vapor transmission rate (MVTR) testing; the MVTR value was reduced from 10.10 g/m^2 24 h for the as-received polymer bag material to 6.31 g/m^2 24 h for the Si-DLC-coated polymer bag material. Water stability tests were used to understand the moisture resistance of the Si-DLC coatings; the results demonstrated the stability of Si-DLC coatings in contact with water up to 100 degrees C for 4 h. A peel-off adhesion test using scotch tape also showed good adhesion of the Si-DLC film to the substrate in contact with water up to 100 degrees C for 4 h. The results of the study indicate that SI-DLC coatings can improve the moisture vapor transmission properties of polymer bags.

The information obtained in these studies will serve as the basis for a material property-biological performance database, in which the associations among cell-material interactions, protein-material interactions, and diamond-like carbon processing parameters will be considered. This database will be of interest to manufacturers who may be interested in coating medical devices with diamond-like carbon coatings.


Last Modified: 08/10/2024
Modified by: Roger J Narayan
